comment.text: Catalyzes the release of fatty acids from phospholipids. It has been implicated in normal phospholipid remodeling, nitric oxide-induced or vasopressin-induced arachidonic acid release and in leukotriene and prostaglandin production. May participate in fas mediated apoptosis and in regulating transmembrane ion flux in glucose-stimulated B-cells. Has a role in cardiolipin (CL) deacylation. Required for both speed and directionality of monocyte MCP1/CCL2-induced chemotaxis through regulation of F-actin polymerization at the pseudopods.
Isoform ankyrin-iPLA2-1 and isoform ankyrin-iPLA2-2, which lack the catalytic domain, are probably involved in the negative regulation of iPLA2 activity.
Recruited to the membrane-enriched pseudopod upon MCP1/CCL2 stimulation in monocytes.
Four different transcripts were found to be expressed in a distinct tissue distribution.

disease.name: Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation 2B
disease.description: A neurodegenerative disorder associated with iron accumulation in the brain, primarily in the basal ganglia. It is characterized by progressive extrapyramidal dysfunction leading to rigidity, dystonia, dysarthria and sensorimotor impairment.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

disease.name: Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation 2A
disease.description: A neurodegenerative disease characterized by pathologic axonal swelling and spheroid bodies in the central nervous system. Onset is within the first 2 years of life with death by age 10 years.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

disease.name: Parkinson disease 14
disease.description: An adult-onset progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by parkinsonism, dystonia, severe cognitive decline, cerebral and cerebellar atrophy and absent iron in the basal ganglia on magnetic resonance imaging.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
Potential target for therapeutic intervention of Barth syndrome.
